I've been using Jetpack Compose since its very first alpha releases in 2020 and have enjoyed every minute. 

At Cuvva, I made one of the initial production commits incorporating Jetpack Compose in late 2020. Our team subsequently participated in a research program with Google¹ that was showcased at Google I/O 2021. 

I've had the pleasure of creating Android Design Systems using both the traditional Android View system and Jetpack Compose. For me, Jetpack Compose represents a significant step forward for the Android UI toolkit.
¹Cuvva builds faster and with higher quality with Compose

I\'ve been a fan of Material Design since its introduction in 2014, as it was my gateway to understanding Design Systems and UI design principles.\n\nI\'ve worked extensively with Material Design 2 and Material Design 3 (which incorporates Material You). Currently, I\'m diving into the expressive capabilities of Material Design 3, and I plan to migrate this app to these advancements as soon as possible.

I'm a fan of app modularization. Every project and team requires a unique strategy, and there are always trade-offs to consider.

My experience ranges from applications with a single module to those with over a thousand. I've migrated apps from monolithic designs to hundreds of modules, and it still amazes me how many ways modularization can be approached. 

While the benefits are numerous and not always immediately obvious, I'm particularly fond of the advantages it ultimately brings to a project.

I remember when the consensus grew that putting everything into a single Activity wasn\'t a sustainable approach. Nowadays, discussions often highlight that an overabundance of layers and abstractions can also be problematic. Android architecture has certainly come a long way!\n\nConsidering the journey through various software design patterns (like MVP, MVVM, MVC, and MVI), architectural solutions such as Clean Architecture, and the SOLID principles, I enjoy exploring what truly remains relevant and what new paradigms are emerging for Android Engineering in this ever-changing landscape.
